definition: lit. to toss a stone to find out what's ahead (idiom)/fig. to test the waters
to cast/to send/to throw oneself (into the river etc)/to seek refuge/to place oneself into the hands of
dry measure for grain equal to ten dou 斗/ten pecks/one hundred liters
surname Shi
rock/stone/stone inscription/one of the eight categories of ancient musical instruments 八音[ba1 yin1]
to ask
surname Lu
road/CL:條|条[tiao2]/journey/route/line (bus etc)/sort/kind

sentences.english: The gentleman raised the issue very sharp, presumably to testing the waters, right?
sentences.chinese: 呢位阿生提嘅问题好尖锐，大概系想投石问路啩？

sentences.english: A television program of cross century try showed months before the test was thrown stone to detect the road.
sentences.chinese: 早前的一个电视节目“跨世纪的审判”则是投石问路。

definition: a deliberate show of strength as a warning
lit. to pull a snake from its hole/to expose a malefactor (idiom)
delaying tactics/stalling/measures to stave off an attack/stratagem to win a respite
to beat sb at their own game (idiom)
lit. please Sir, get into the boiling pot (idiom)/fig. to give sb a taste of his own medicine
to defeat the enemy by capturing their chief (idiom)
to threaten the east and strike to the west (idiom)/to create a diversion
to lure the tiger from its domain in the mountains (idiom)/to lure an enemy away from his territory
opposite of 先禮後兵|先礼后兵[xian1 li3 hou4 bing1]
use a long line to catch a big fish (idiom); a long-term plan for major returns
pinyin: fang4 chang2 xian4 diao4 da4 yu2

definition: lit. secretly crossing the Wei River 渭河[Wei4 He2] at Chencang (idiom, refers to a stratagem used by Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] in 206 BC against Xiang Yu 項羽|项羽[Xiang4 Yu3] of Chu)/fig. to feign one thing while doing another/to cheat under cover of a diversion
to sound out opinions/to get sb's views by polite or indirect questioning
to take drastic measures to deal with a situation/to pull the carpet from under sb
to make inquiries about sb or sth/to fish for information
see 小試牛刀|小试牛刀[xiao3 shi4 niu2 dao1]
peaceful measures before using force (idiom); diplomacy before violence/jaw-jaw is better than war-war
